This supersedes IRM 5.5.2, Probate Proceedings, dated February 01, 2011.
Small Business/Self-Employed Collection Employees

Proceedings

) This IRM section provides information on probate proceedings and identifies the need for administrative or judicial action on decedent cases. Use the mation in this section to guide you through probate proceedings and to evaluate and protect the Government’s interest during these proceedings. (

) This section explains the progression of probate proceedings and is meant emphasize the time sensitive deadlines during the proceedings that require action to be taken on behalf of the Service. It further explains necessary and reasonable expenses to assist in determinations of what expenses are allowable, insurance policies that may pay expenses, the priority of the tax lien and explains solvent and insolvent estates. (
) Additional resources: (cid:
) Use IRM
, Legal Reference Guide, Insolvency and Decedent Estates, and confer with Area Counsel when confronted with decedent issues beyond your scope of knowledge and expertise. (cid:

, Survivors, Executors and Administrators (

) This section provides the general steps taken in probate proceedings. These steps will vary based on state law and the type of administration (dependent of Probate independent). Since laws vary from state to state you should conduct research on probate law for the state you work and check your local law

The first step is usually to apply for administration or probate of the will there is one. An executor or administrator is then appointed by the will by the court. Typically probate bond requirements are determined this step. Sometimes, the court will approve administration without court intervention indicating an independent (or unsupervised) administration. Requirements may be outlined in the will or in the letters testamentary.

The estate administrator is responsible for gathering the decedent’s and placing them under the administrator’s control. They are given pos- session and control of the decedent’s assets and are charged with the payment of the decedent’s debts. Typically the estate administrator will open accounts in the name of the estate and contract a bond if

The estate administrator must file an inventory of the estate assets with the probate court. State statutes will dictate the time period in which the inventory needs to be filed, generally it is within
days of appointment the estate administrator. All property and debts of the decedent are in the inventory with a value at the time of death.

A newspaper notice is published notifying the creditors of the death and creditor’s obligation to present claims for payment. Claims include all debts incurred by the decedent prior to his death. State define a time period, usually
to

days, in which claims must be for consideration. A Notice of Creditors may be sent to known requesting a claim to be filed within a specific time period. The notice indicate that untimely claims will be barred forever.

At the end of the specified period to file claims the estate administrator determines the claims to be paid, in whole or in part, in accordance with statutory provisions. He must also resolve payment of expenses related estate administration, such as funeral expenses, legal fees, cost of and any expenses related to maintenance of the decedent’s property (
) Internal Revenue Manual
(02-01-2011) Progression of Proceedings

The first step is usually to apply for administration or probate of the will if there is one. An executor or administrator is then appointed by the will or by the court. Typically probate bond requirements are determined during this step. Sometimes, the court will approve administration without court intervention indicating an independent (or unsupervised) administration. Requirements may be outlined in the will or in the letters testamentary.

The estate administrator is responsible for gathering the decedent’s assets and placing them under the administrator’s control. They are given pos- session and control of the decedent’s assets and are charged with the payment of the decedent’s debts. Typically the estate administrator will open accounts in the name of the estate and contract a bond if required.

The estate administrator must file an inventory of the estate assets with the probate court. State statutes will dictate the time period in which the inventory needs to be filed, generally it is within
days of appointment of the estate administrator. All property and debts of the decedent are listed in the inventory with a value at the time of death.

A newspaper notice is published notifying the creditors of the decedent’s death and creditor’s obligation to present claims for payment. Claims include all debts incurred by the decedent prior to his death. State statutes define a time period, usually
to

days, in which claims must be filed for consideration. A Notice of Creditors may be sent to known lienholders requesting a claim to be filed within a specific time period. The notice may indicate that untimely claims will be barred forever.

At the end of the specified period to file claims the estate administrator determines the claims to be paid, in whole or in part, in accordance with statutory provisions. He must also resolve payment of expenses related to estate administration, such as funeral expenses, legal fees, cost of notices and any expenses related to maintenance of the decedent’s property after
5.5 Decedent Estates and Estate
death. A Notice or Petition of Proposed Distribution that outlines the to be paid and the amount to be paid, is usually filed with the court for judge’s approval.
The estate administrator is responsible for filing tax returns, including plicable tax returns in accordance with federal or state laws.

When all debts, expenses and taxes have been paid the estate trator files a final accounting. This accounting informs the court and beneficiaries of all property and income received, expenses paid and amount remaining for distribution.
When the final accounting is approved, the court will order the estate ministrator to distribute the assets of the estate.

After distribution the estate administrator files an affidavit of closing with the court. If a probate bond was required the court (or court order) the surety company that the estate administrator has complied with all orders and the bond is terminated. (

) Actions taken in probate proceedings are noted on a docket sheet. The sheet should be copied (or printed if available electronically) and added to case file. The docket sheet will outline what has happened in the such as orders, hearings, filings or motions. (

) Collection actions may continue during probate proceedings unless the are under the control of the court in a dependent or supervised proceeding. The following IRM sections provide guidance concerning collection actions: IRM
, Probate and Non-Probate Property, IRM
, General tion on Probate Proceedings, and IRM
, Working Decedent Cases, has numerous pertinent sections. (

is prepared by revenue officers and advisors to show the taxes accrued by the taxpayer prior to the taxpayer’s death. This form also administrators of potential personal liability if taxes are not paid. Generally state probate courts will not accept this form as a substitute for a creditor presented for payment. This form should be sent to the estate administrator a successor administrator as soon as the Service learns who has authority over estate assets. (

is a proof of claim. It is a written statement that sets forth a against the probate estate of a deceased debtor for tax liabilities accrued to death. This form is prepared and monitored by advisors. State statutes specify if the claim should be filed with the court or mailed/presented to the estate administrator. Generally a proof of claim should be sent to the estate administrator and should also be filed with the court in all probate unless the local law guide specifies otherwise. IRM
, Proof of Claim cedures in Decedent Cases, provides further guidance on filing proofs of (

is used to show taxes that have accrued after the probate ing has commenced. Typically taxes reflected on this form result from estate Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

death. A Notice or Petition of Proposed Distribution that outlines the to be paid and the amount to be paid, is usually filed with the court for judge’s approval.
The estate administrator is responsible for filing tax returns, including plicable tax returns in accordance with federal or state laws.

When all debts, expenses and taxes have been paid the estate adminis- trator files a final accounting. This accounting informs the court and beneficiaries of all property and income received, expenses paid and amount remaining for distribution.
When the final accounting is approved, the court will order the estate ministrator to distribute the assets of the estate.

After distribution the estate administrator files an affidavit of closing with the court. If a probate bond was required the court (or court order) the surety company that the estate administrator has complied with all orders and the bond is terminated.
A Notice or Petition of Proposed Distribution that outlines the claims be paid and the amount to be paid, is usually filed with the court for the

administrators of potential personal liability if taxes are not paid. Generally state probate courts will not accept this form as a substitute for a creditor claim presented for payment. This form should be sent to the estate administrator or a successor administrator as soon as the Service learns who has authority over estate assets. (
) Form

is a proof of claim. It is a written statement that sets forth a claim against the probate estate of a deceased debtor for tax liabilities accrued prior to death. This form is prepared and monitored by advisors. State statutes will specify if the claim should be filed with the court or mailed/presented to the estate administrator. Generally a proof of claim should be sent to the estate administrator and should also be filed with the court in all probate proceedings unless the local law guide specifies otherwise. IRM
, Proof of Claim Pro- cedures in Decedent Cases, provides further guidance on filing proofs of claim. (
) Form
is used to show taxes that have accrued after the probate proceed-
Form 2373 is used to show taxes that have accrued after the probate proceed- ing has commenced. Typically taxes reflected on this form result from estate
income tax (Form
), payroll taxes for a business operated after death of the taxpayer or excise taxes. This form is filed with the court. IRM
, Claiming Taxes as an Administrative Expense, provides on use of this form. (

) The ICS history must be documented to reflect the date on which a form is sent to an estate administrator to establish when they were put on notice of taxes due. Consideration should be given to sending these forms by certified mail and a copy should be maintained with the case file. (

) If a successor administrator is appointed, notice of taxes due must be sent make the new administrator aware of the outstanding tax liability or unfiled returns. If notice was sent to the prior administrator send a copy of that to the successor administrator. (

) If a Notice of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL) has been recorded against a taxpayer during his lifetime, its priority is preserved after death and valid against other creditors (except as provided in IRC section
), including future ries whose claims come into existence subsequent to the Federal tax lien are debts of the estate). (
) The death of the debtor does not extinguish the federal tax lien, nor affect priority among multiple security interests in the debtor’s property. (

) Federal law controls in situations in which a federal tax lien competes with interest under state law or by contract. However, the Service may in its dis- cretion not assert priority of its federal tax lien over reasonable expenses of the estate, to the extent that such expenses are not covered by an insurance policy, trust or other similar benefit that covers the cost of istrative expenses of the estate. State statutes may limit the amount of reasonable administrative expenses permitted to be paid during probate. (
) A state statute may not subordinate a federal tax lien to interests that Congress has not specifically permitted to prime the lien. State law is to the extent that it conflicts with federal law. (
) IRC
(a) provides that specific valid liens on the decedent’s property at death that were fully perfected prior to the NFTL will have priority. (
) When an issue arises concerning priority of the federal tax lien, particularly court proceeding, consult with Area Counsel. For further guidance on see IRM
, Referral to Area Counsel for Judicial Action. (
) For additional guidance on federal tax lien preparation, filing and attachment see IRM
, Notice of Federal Tax Lien. (
) A solvent estate is one in which the value of estate assets exceeds the estate’s debts. (

) An insolvent estate is one that has insufficient assets or equity in assets to cover its debt. A “no asset” estate is a type of insolvent estate from which there is nothing to collect. Although there may be assets in this type of insolvent estate, the assets have little or no equity. If there actually are no assets then it is unlikely there is a need for a probate proceeding. Internal Revenue Manual
(04-05-2012) Priority of the Federal Tax Lien
The death of the debtor does not extinguish the federal tax lien, nor affect the priority among multiple security interests in the debtor’s property.

Federal law controls in situations in which a federal tax lien competes with interest under state law or by contract. However, the Service may in its dis- cretion not assert priority of its federal tax lien over reasonable administrative expenses of the estate, to the extent that such expenses are not covered by an insurance policy, trust or other similar benefit that covers the cost of admin- istrative expenses of the estate. State statutes may limit the amount of reasonable administrative expenses permitted to be paid during probate.
6323(a) provides that specific valid liens on the decedent’s property owed death that were fully perfected prior to the NFTL will have priority.
(02-01-2011) Solvent or Insolvent Estate

An insolvent estate is one that has insufficient assets or equity in assets to cover its debt. A “no asset” estate is a type of insolvent estate from which there is nothing to collect. Although there may be assets in this type of insolvent estate, the assets have little or no equity. If there actually are no assets then it is unlikely there is a need for a probate proceeding.
Decedent Estates and Estate (

) “Insolvent estate” is a broadly used term. Some documents use the term “insolvent estate” to refer to estates that cannot pay all claims presented. priority claims are paid the estate is then insolvent to pay the full amount of other (lower priority) claims. For this reason it is very important that notices of proposed distribution are carefully reviewed to make sure a federal tax claim in the proper payment category. If the federal tax claim is not in the proper payment category Counsel should be consulted on judicial action necessary ensure payment. Review federal law concerning priority of federal and state taxes. (
) Creditors within a given class or category are paid on a pro rata basis when there is not enough money to pay all of the creditors in that class or category. (

) Before any money can be distributed to beneficiaries all the debts of the deceased must be paid, including the funeral bill, any medical bills, taxes and credit cards. This might require the sale of assets if the deceased did not set aside enough to cover all debts. (

) A declining real estate and securities market may impact the administration of probate estates. An estate administrator may discover that an estate that was solvent at inception has suddenly become insolvent. In such case, the trator may need to act swiftly to properly administer and settle the estate to avoid potential personal liability. (

) Expenses related to the decedent’s estate are known as “administrative expenses”. They include any expenses related to maintenance of the dece- dent’s property incurred after the decedent’s death. Expenses are paid from the estate before assets are distributed to the beneficiaries or heirs. (

) The Service in its discretion may permit reasonable, necessary expenses to be paid before a federal tax lien. Such expenses must be examined to determine if an expense is reasonable and necessary to the administration of the estate. Reasonable and necessary expenses should not be permitted ahead of a tax lien if such expenses are already covered by an insurance policy, trust or other similar benefit that covers such costs. State statutes may limit the amount permitted to be paid for administrative expenses in probate. Inform the administrator that such planned expense payments may not be made prior to tax payments. Contact Area Counsel if an administrator refuses to pay a tax lien. For more information see IRM
, Priority of the Tax Lien, and IRM
, Referral to Area Counsel for Judicial Action. (

) The major expenses of probate include: a. the court filing fee - some states set filing fees based on the value of estate’s assets, other states may have a set fee schedule b. personal representative (executor or administrator) fee - an estate ministrator may charge a fee for services. In some states the amount is regulated by statute and in others it is what is reasonable for the work performed. If the estate administrator is derelict in carrying out his or her duties, the court may even reduce or deny compensation. c. posting a bond - if the estate administrator is asked to post bond, this is to protect heirs and creditors from being harmed by the negligence or feasance of the administrator. In such cases, the bond will make the
5.5 Decedent Estates and Estate
Creditors within a given class or category are paid on a pro rata basis when there is not enough money to pay all of the creditors in that class or category.
The major expenses of probate include: a. the court filing fee
some states set filing fees based on the value of estate’s assets, other states may have a set fee schedule b. personal representative (executor or administrator) fee
an estate ad

ministrator may charge a fee for services. In some states the amount is regulated by statute and in others it is what is reasonable for the work performed. If the estate administrator is derelict in carrying out his or her duties, the court may even reduce or deny compensation. c. posting a bond
if the estate administrator is asked to post bond, this is to protect heirs and creditors from being harmed by the negligence or feasance of the administrator. In such cases, the bond will make the

can be costly and depends on the value of the property subject to the bond. d. publication and legal notices - a publication fee is charged by the local newspaper, which announces the person’s death and how interested ties/creditors can contact the attorney or file a claim. e. tax preparer fees - expenses may be incurred for preparation of pre death income tax returns, estate tax returns, estate income tax returns business tax returns if a sole proprietorship or partnership is in the f. property appraisals - an appraisal is sometimes necessary for real or personal property such as jewelry or artwork. The fee may be statutory based on a percentage of the appraisal of the appraised value of the asset. g. attorney fees - this is usually the largest expense of probate. In some states the attorney’s fees are set as a flat amount. In others, they are based on the size and complexity of the estate. h. funeral expenses - may be paid from the estate, a trust or by a burial life insurance policy. Typically a burial insurance policy has a specified coverage limit, see IRM

, for further discussion on insurance policies. i. family allowance - the family allowance is an award made to the surviving spouse and the minor children to live on during the administra- tion of the estate. The dollar amount of these allowances are usually addressed in the state probate provisions. The family may also receive proceeds from a life insurance policy that may be payable to the spouse or the estate at death. (
) The estate administrator must carefully examine the accuracy and validity of claims/expenses submitted and, if appropriate compromise and settle such ministrative expense claims. (

) In accordance with state law, claims and expenses are categorized for in which they will be paid. For federal tax claims, federal law controls the priority of payments of federal tax liens. To the extent there is a conflict between state and federal law, federal law controls. Contact Area Counsel for guidance.
life insurance policy. Typically a burial insurance policy has a specified coverage limit, see IRM

, for further discussion on insurance policies. i. family allowance - the family allowance is an award made to the surviving spouse and the minor children to live on during the administra- tion of the estate. The dollar amount of these allowances are usually addressed in the state probate provisions. The family may also receive proceeds from a life insurance policy that may be payable to the spouse or the estate at death. (
) The estate administrator must carefully examine the accuracy and validity of claims/expenses submitted and, if appropriate compromise and settle such ministrative expense claims. (

) In accordance with state law, claims and expenses are categorized for in which they will be paid. For federal tax claims, federal law controls the priority of payments of federal tax liens. To the extent there is a conflict between state and federal law, federal law controls. Contact Area Counsel guidance. (

) If a Notice of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL) has been recorded against a taxpayer during his lifetime, its priority is preserved after death and valid against other creditors (except as provided in IRC section
), including future ries whose claims come into existence subsequent to the Federal tax lien are debts of the estate). See IRM
, concerning lien priority. (

) Reasonable administrative expenses are limited to expenses for preserving and marshalling estate assets. Consideration should be given to how does allowance of this expense benefit the Government giving up its lien position. (

) Generally there are state law provisions that dictate “reasonable expenses”. Some state law guidelines are based on the size of the estate, other allow a set percentage to be paid as an allowable expense. Some expenses can be negotiated to a certain extent by the estate administrator, others such as court filing fees are not negotiable. State standards should be considered, but are not controlling, when making a determination if fees charged are reasonable.

If a Notice of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL) has been recorded against a taxpayer during his lifetime, its priority is preserved after death and valid against other creditors (except as provided in IRC section 6323), including future beneficia- ries whose claims come into existence subsequent to the Federal tax lien (they are debts of the estate). See IRM 5.5.2.4, concerning lien priority.

Generally there are state law provisions that dictate “reasonable expenses”. Some state law guidelines are based on the size of the estate, other provisions allow a set percentage to be paid as an allowable expense. Some expenses can be negotiated to a certain extent by the estate administrator, others such as court filing fees are not negotiable. State standards should be considered, but are not controlling, when making a determination if fees charged are un
5.5 Decedent Estates and Estate
When determining allowance for necessary administrative expenses, consider the following factors:

a. What is necessary to maintain the asset until it is transferred to a beneficiary? Those expenses that are necessary to administer the estate assets in accordance with the will or state law distribution due to the taxpayer dying intestate. For example, a beneficiary is living in the decedent’s home and incurs normal living expenses such as water bills, heating bills and pool cleaning, these normal living expenses for the beneficiary are not allowed. A necessary expense would be a payment such as insurance and property tax payments, to protect the property from damage or foreclosure. b. Expenses incurred to transfer or clear title to beneficiary or third parties

limited to expenses that are the result of settling the decedent’s interest in the property or vesting good title to the property in the name of the beneficiaries or third parties. An example would be for a vehicle that is devised to a beneficiary, a necessary expense would be to title the car to the beneficiary but not to make any repairs. By will or state law the benefi

ciary may inherit the property but the estate administrator is not required to repair property before transferring it to the beneficiary. If a piece of real property is being sold, only attorney fees for title work and expenses to vest good title will be considered an expense. c. When are attorney fees excessive? Check local probate code to determine if thresholds have been established. The attorney’s billing state

ments will provide information on what actions the attorney has taken on behalf of the estate to generate the fees. These commissions or fees should be limited to expenses for preserving or marshalling estate assets. Fees that have not been incurred or are estimated are not allowable. d. Attorney fees incidental to litigation incurred by the beneficiaries are expenses charged against the beneficiaries personally and are not administration expenses. The Service needs to carefully consider attorney fees that are charged for litigation concerning assets when it is unlikely that after payment of taxes and other creditors these assets would be transferred to beneficiaries. For example, beneficiaries are suing the estate for ownership of a house but the house must be sold to pay claims against the estate. Therefore attorney fees should not be allowed since the asset must be sold to pay claims and it is unlikely the beneficiary would receive the property because liquidation of this asset is necessary to pay claims before a distribution can be made. Fees may be deemed unreasonable if they are incurred in support of unreasonable activity, such as positions that are frivolous or without substantial merit.
Note: Attorney’s lien under state law arising from the recovery of money for the estate may be entitled to priority over a tax lien for which a NFTL is filed
page 7
parent has sufficient income, trust distributions or life insurance to support minor or incapacitated children this payment would not be allowed ahead of the tax lien. To determine income the Form
, Indi- vidual Income Tax Return, may provide information, also see IRM Insurance Policies, and IRM
, Reporting Estate Income. The administrator may also be able to provide information. (

) Miscellaneous administration expenses necessarily incurred in preserving distributing the estate are allowable. These expenses include appraiser’s and accountant fees, certain court costs, and costs of storing or maintaining of the estate. (

) The expenses of selling assets are allowable only if the sale is necessary to pay the decedent’s debts, the expenses of administration, or taxes, or to preserve the estate or carry out distribution. (

) Employees are required to request and review documents that substantiate expenses such as itemized statements of service, invoices for payment, etc. documentation cannot be provided, employees should not permit theses expenses to be paid ahead of a decedent’s federal taxes (similar to on a Form
- if deductions cannot be substantiated they are not Statements should include the exact nature of the claim, the name of the creditor, and the time period covered by the claim. (
) Property taxes are only necessary administrative expenses if they accrue death. (

) Inquire what non-probate assets the heirs received. Non-probate assets as life insurance, burial policies, certificates of deposit, jointly held bank accounts or investment accounts that are payable on death and do not go through probate. These non-probate assets provide immediate cash at death to pay expenses, debts and final income taxes. (

) If provision for payment of funeral and administrative expenses is made by insurance, a trust or otherwise these expenses should not be permitted to be paid ahead of federal taxes to the extent non-probate assets are available. Only amounts not reimbursed by insurance or otherwise will be allowed of taxes. In the case of a trust that provides for payment of estate tion expenses the trust document will need to be secured and provisions for payment reviewed. (

) Employees must inquire about pre-paid funeral plans, burial and insurance policies payable to the estate that provide for payment of administrative expenses. If these type of provisions have been made by the decedent, payment of such expenses should not be allowed ahead of a claim for taxes accruing prior to death. (
) A general rule when considering allowance of funeral expenses is exclusion items that benefit the attendees/beneficiaries rather than the deceased. (
) Expenses of a decedent’s last illness are a debt of the decedent and not entitled to priority under
U.S.C.
Internal Revenue Manual

Employees are required to request and review documents that substantiate expenses such as itemized statements of service, invoices for payment, etc. If documentation cannot be provided, employees should not permit theses expenses to be paid ahead of a decedent’s federal taxes (similar to deductions on a Form 1040 - if deductions cannot be substantiated they are not allowed). Statements should include the exact nature of the claim, the name of the creditor, and the time period covered by the claim.
A general rule when considering allowance of funeral expenses is exclusion of items that benefit the attendees/beneficiaries rather than the deceased.
Decedent Estates and Estate (

) It is the responsibility of the estate administrator to control, maintain, and dis- tribute entrusted property in a manner defined by law. Monitor taxes that accrue during a proceeding to ensure that timely claims are filed. The types of liabilities may accrue during the administration of a proceeding: (cid:
) payroll or income taxes from the operation of a business. (cid:
) excise taxes. (cid:
) income taxes for the estate (Form

) When a fiduciary is appointed by the court to operate a decedent/insolvent business or to oversee the administration of an estate, send a letter to the fiduciary advising of the responsibility for filing and paying federal taxes a new EIN as described in Pub.
, Understanding Your EIN and Pub. Survivors, Executors and Administrators. (
) Use Form

, Statement of Internal Revenue Taxes Due as an Expense Administration of an Estate, to claim taxes accrued during a court This form should be filed with the court and a copy sent to the fiduciary re- sponsible for paying the taxes, for example the fiduciary operating the business or overseeing the administration of the estate. (
) Federal Tax Deposit (FTD) Alerts are sent directly from Master File to Inte- grated Collection System (ICS) for assignment to a revenue officer to make contact within
calendar days of receipt of the alert. If an FTD alert is received follow guidelines in IRM

, FTD Alerts, to determine if the business is in compliance with tax deposit requirements and resolve the alert appropriately. If the business is not in compliance and there is an open proceeding the Form
should be sent to the fiduciary responsible for paying the taxes. If advisory has an open Non-Field Other Investigation to monitor a proof of claim notify advisory to prepare and send the Form (
) If a person operating the business is different from the estate administrator and it is unclear whether the person operating the business is a fiduciary appointed by the court, send a Form
to the estate administrator, in addition to the person operating the business. (
) Life insurance is a contract between the insurer and the policy owner a benefit is paid to the designated beneficiary if an insured event (death) occurs which is covered by the policy. (

) The beneficiary is designated in the policy contract and could be any of the following: a. Spouse and/or children to provide for living expenses b. Owner’s estate to pay administrative expenses c. A revocable trust, which may be funded by policy proceeds to pay istrative expenses d. Owner’s business to maintain operation of the business or to redeem stock of the owner at death, commonly known as “key man insurance” (

) Burial policies cover funeral expenses, such as mortuary expenses, casket, cemetery plot, paying off debt, the cost of administering probate or medical bills. The policy may cover specific products and services or it may be to make a lump sum payment to pay associated expenses. Secure a copy of the policy to determine coverage. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
J
5.5 Decedent Estates and Estate

It is the responsibility of the estate administrator to control, maintain, and dis- tribute entrusted property in a manner defined by law. Monitor taxes that accrue during a proceeding to ensure that timely claims are filed. The following types of liabilities may accrue during the administration of a proceeding:

) Quite often the Service gets involved after these expenses are paid, these expenses or reimbursement of these expenses are not allowed payment of federal taxes accruing before death. Employees must inquire insurance policies, trusts, or other similar benefits that cover administrative expenses, as well as state statutes that limit the amount permitted to be for administrative expenses in probate. (
) Internal research can be performed to see if a Form
-R, Distributions From Pensions, Annuities, Retirement or Profit-Sharing Plans, IRAs, Contracts, etc., is reported by a beneficiary on their Form
This would reported on lines
a and
b of Form
or lines
a and
b of Form

A. Beneficiaries may be identified by a will, obituary, documents that reflect payable on death designations, such as signature cards on bank accounts, term documents of certificates of deposit, or a Form
, Life Insurance Statement. (

) If the decedent was a veteran, expenses may have been paid by the Administration as part of burial and memorial benefits. Information burial benefits for veterans can be researched at www.va.gov under the benefits tab. (

) An asset that has a beneficiary designation (such as a retirement account, life insurance policy or a payable on death account) is not controlled by a Beneficiary designations will take precedence over the will. This type of account or policy won’t have to go through probate. (

) An account or policy may have multiple beneficiaries designated. The beneficiary or beneficiaries inherit first. If they are dead or they die with the owner of the account or policy, the assets go to any secondary that have been designated. (

) If all of the transfer on death beneficiaries predecease the deceased the proceeds may pass to the estate and become probate property, to be tributed in accordance with state probate law or the will. Area Counsel be consulted in this type of circumstance before collection action is taken against the asset. (

) In some proceedings the estate administrator will be required to post bond. probate bond is a bond issued on the performance of an administrator. Its purpose is to protect heirs and creditors from being harmed by the or malfeasance of the administrator. It is like an insurance policy. Obtaining probate bond can be costly and the cost depends on the value of the subject to the bond. (

) Requirements for a bond will be reflected in documents such as: a. the will - which would designate an executor and typically specifies if person has the authority to act with or without bond and whether court pervision is required (independent or dependent administration). b. letters testamentary - the court will approve appointment of an estate administrator, set forth the type of administration (independent or dependent administration) and set the amount of a required bond. (
) If during probate proceedings the estate administrator requests that the amount be reduced, advisors should determine if the IRS debt has been (

If during probate proceedings the estate administrator requests that the bond amount be reduced, advisors should determine if the IRS debt has been ac-
Decedent Estates and Estate knowledged and whether the proposed reduced amount is of an adequate amount to pay all taxes due if necessary. (

) Probate bonds are a potential collection source in the event of administrator negligence or malfeasance. In this case, consult Area Counsel for advice as how to file a claim in probate court to enforce liability on the probate bond. aware that generally a bond will be terminated after the estate proceedings officially closed. If an estate proceeding has officially closed, consult Area Counsel. (
) The Service would have to authorize Department of Justice to make a claim a bond, just like any other collection suit. See IRM
, Action on Bonds. (

) There will be circumstances when administrative actions are impractical or effective and a referral should be sent to Area Counsel to consider judicial action to maximize collection efforts. A referral or memorandum should facts of the case, issues in question, include the docket sheet, a complete history transcript, and all related documentation/correspondence that will in decision making on the issue referred. (
) See IRM
, Litigation and Judgments - Suits by the United States, for formation regarding requests for legal action against a taxpayer to collect unpaid taxes. (

) Depending on the issue involved the following factors may need to be addressed when making a referral: a. When was the assessment made; when was the lien recorded; when estate assets distributed or sold? b. Has the estate administrator been notified of the lien’s priority and for payment made? c. Is there any indication that the tax lien will not be paid ahead of other claims (such as distributions made to creditors other than those in IRC

(a) through (c))? d. Are unnecessary or unreasonable expenses accrued after death being paid ahead of the tax lien? e. Are heirs being reimbursed for expenses (such as funeral expenses) were paid from insurance proceeds, non-probate assets or sources than estate funds? f. Are assets available to pay the taxes due? g. Are estate assets involved in litigation with creditors that are not ahead the tax lien? h. If there is a situation where an estate administrator is not handling the estate affairs, not paying creditors or if expenses or claims are being im- properly paid before taxes accrued against the decedent or the estate. It may be necessary to request appointment of a receiver or successor to handle affairs for the estate; another action that may be taken is to file a motion to compel an accounting. (

) Should you come across any of the following situations notify Area Counsel and make an expeditious referral as they may have a short time frame to respond to the court: a. Rejection of proofs of claim b. Order or motion to appear in court Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

If there is a situation where an estate administrator is not handling the estate affairs, not paying creditors or if expenses or claims are being im- properly paid before taxes accrued against the decedent or the estate. It may be necessary to request appointment of a receiver or successor to handle affairs for the estate; another action that may be taken is to file a motion to compel an accounting. Should you come across any of the following situations notify Area Counsel

Competing lien issues, for example a suit to settle competing claims Competing federal agencies for priority payment Litigation involving assets in which an assessment has been made death Request for assistance from U.S. Attorney on a probate proceeding Assistance when an estate administrator is not taking action to pay creditors or improperly paying expenses or claims of the decedent or estate Petition to sell property which does not provide for payment to IRS sale proceeds Anything in an application, motion, notice, objection, or petition filed the Court that seeks to contest, defeat, dispute, disregard or the IRS claim, or which may have that effect. Time is of the essence in such cases because a notice of removal to the federal district court of dispute of the merits of a federal tax assessment or lien must generally filed within thirty days of receipt by the IRS of the initial pleading such an issue. It is essential that such issues be litigated in the federal courts whenever possible.

) A decedent’s estate or trust is a separate legal entity for federal tax Every estate or trust that is required to file Form
, United States Tax Return for Estates and Trusts, must have an EIN. (
) The estate administrator or fiduciary of a decedent’s estate or trust uses

to report: a. The income, deductions, gains, losses, etc., of the estate or trust b. The income that is either accumulated or held for future distribution or tributed currently to the beneficiaries c. Any income tax liability of the estate or trust (
) Refer to the instructions for Form
for information regarding filing ments, filing dates, estimated tax payments and income reported on various schedules. (

is used to report the beneficiary’s share of the estate or trust. It gives names and SSN’s, which is helpful if they need to be concerning distributions received. The amounts on the K-

Tax liability can be forgiven, or refunded if already paid, if while on active duty, a member of the U.S. Armed Forces dies in a combat zone, or from wounds, disease or injury incurred during active service in a combat zone.
This forgiveness applies to the year the death occurred, as well as any earlier tax year that ended after the member entered the combat zone.
See IRC section 692, Income taxes of members of Armed Forces, and victims of certain terrorist attacks on death.
